required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Charge: A Text Messaging-based Weight Loss Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: Charge: Optimizing a Standalone Text Messaging-Based Weight Loss Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates different versions of a text messaging-based app for weight loss. This study will place participants to 1 of 32 experimental conditions that reflect different texting components and levels. Participants will be randomized to a condition. The investigators will recruit 448 adults into a 6-month weight loss program, with an additional follow-up 6-months after the intervention ends.

detailed_description.textblock: Standalone text messaging-based weight loss treatments are scalable and can achieve population reach. However, these interventions are also modular; they can be delivered independently to maximize cost-effectiveness or combined with other approaches (e.g. provider counseling) to maximize outcomes. This study is a 12-month experimental trial among 448 adults with obesity. All participants will receive a core 6-month weight loss texting intervention that includes tailored behavior change goals, interactive self-monitoring, automated feedback, and skills training. Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 32 different experimental conditions.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The investigators will use a full factorial design to randomize participants to experimental conditions that reflect the texting intervention components: motivational messaging (self- vs expert-generated), texting frequency (daily vs weekly), reminders (one reminder v. multiple reminders), feedback type (summary score v. specific feedback) and comparison unit (to self v. to a group of people). The full factorial design is power efficient, logistically feasible (because we manipulate conditions using technology) and will allow the investigators to examine the most important main and interaction effects among components.

secondary_outcome.description: To experimentally determine the effects of text messaging components and levels on change in diet
To experimentally determine the effects of text messaging components and levels on change in physical activity

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in categorical weight loss (> 5%) at 6-months
secondary_outcome.description: To experimentally determine the effects of text messaging components and levels on change in categorical weight loss (>5%)
To experimentally determine the effects of text messaging components and levels on change in 12-month maintenance of weight loss

To determine how many responses we receive to our questions and to measure associations of engagement with weight change at 6- and 12- months. We will also model trajectories of change in engagement over time
To calculate the cost of the intervention's implementation and compare cost effectiveness of each intervention.

intervention.description: Text messaging-based study to determine effect of different components on weight loss.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- males and females aged 18-65 years
- participants have English language proficiency
- participants have a BMI between 25-40 kg/m2
- Participants will own a smartphone
- Participants will be willing to receive multiple text messages daily.
Exclusion Criteria:
- prior or planned bariatric surgery
- psychiatric hospitalization in past 12 months
- pregnancy, nursing, or planned pregnancy
- history of a cardiovascular event
- history of an eating disorder
- history of a condition (e.g., end stage renal disease, cancer, schizophrenia) or use of medications (e.g., lithium, steroids, anti-psychotics) that would affect weight measurement, for which weight loss is contraindicated, or might promote weight change
- current participation in a weight loss trial and/or recent weight loss > 10%
- investigator discretion for safety reasons

overall_official.affiliation: Bishop-MacDermott Family Professor of Psychology, Global Health & Medicine
